Reader, no story of fictitious woe,</br>Artfully told, here asks thy tenderness;</br>But if thy breast with sympathy can glow</br>For one who tells a tale of deep distress,</br>In truth's own simple, unelaborate dress,</br>To win thy pity mine can scarcely fail;</br>For few, indeed, amid the throng and press</br>Of trials manifold which life assail,</br>Have witness'd scenes more dread than deck my mournful tale.

I was the wife of one who left his home,</br>His friends, and country, — all he held most dear</br>Except myself, to breast the billows' foam,</br>The stormy music of the blast to hear;</br>In foreign climes to know a stranger's cheer,</br>And be a homeless wanderer far and wide;</br>Content by duty's star his course to steer,</br>So he might honour Him who for us died,</br>And preach in distant lands his Lord, the Crucified.

Among the sunny islands of the west</br>His field of labour open'd:  could I stay</br>At home in listless, self-indulgent rest,</br>While he was braving hardships far away?</br>Not thus to love, to honour, and obey,</br>Methought my word was plighted; but where he</br>To whom 'twas given conceiv'd his duty lay,</br>My vow no less appointed mine to be;</br>Therefore I went with him a wanderer o'er the sea.

Not mine his Gospel labours to proclaim;</br>May they be sanctified to those 'mid whom</br>He strove to glorify his Saviour's name;—</br>My heart too keenly, feels a mourner's doom,</br>When I reflect upon his watery tomb,</br>To paint the varied scenes through which we pass'd;</br>Yet with no feelings of desponding gloom,</br>Like her whose starless sky is all o'er-cast,</br>Would I pourtray the one which prov'd on earth our last.

On earth!  alas!  we hardly could be said</br>To part on earth, for foaming seas were round</br>The fragment of a wreck, his dying bed;—</br>Fearful each sight, and terrible each sound</br>We witness'd there; yet in that hour we found</br>Hope's sure and stedfast anchor to the soul;</br>Mortal with immortality was crown'd,</br>And the blest spirit sought its glorious goal,</br>Where blasts can never rave, nor angry billows roll.

Can I, then, mourn for his lamented loss,</br>As one who knows not faith's sustaining spell?</br>He left his home to bear a Saviour's Cross,</br>The tidings of redeeming love to tell,</br>And in that hallow'd cause he meekly fell:</br>Oh!  may I, rather, through his Master's grace,</br>Since memory on our parting can but dwell,</br>The grateful and consoling thought retrace</br>With "glory!"  on his lips he died in my embrace.

This soothing, elevating thought bears up</br>My spirit with the hope his meed is won;</br>It sweetens Sorrow's overflowing cup</br>By the firm faith his race is safely run;</br>Gives strength to say, "God's holy will be done!"</br>And in that strength, yet never known to fail,</br>Power to retrace what memory else would shun,</br>A scene where woman's cheek might well turn pale,</br>Where e'en man's bolder heart might feel its courage quail.

We went on board our ship at sunset hour,</br>The giant deep in peaceful slumber lay;</br>And though, at night, the wild winds' mighty power</br>Its curling billows rous'd to fearful play,</br>We slept in peace:  but, on the following day,</br>The morn was stormy, and the wind a-head;</br>The sea broke o'er us, and the sheeted spray</br>Which, far as eye could reach, around us spread,</br>Gave to the darkening clouds a darkness yet more dread.

Not only he — whose loss my heart must mourn,</br>Was with me in that season of dismay;</br>Brethren and sisters in that bark were borne,</br>Companions with us on our fearful way;</br>Brethren who went, like him, to preach and pray,</br>And sisters, like myself, their lot to share;</br>Their precious babes, too, in life's opening day,</br>Objects of many a fond parental prayer;—</br>Oh!  when did wave-tost bark a freight more guileless bear?

For e'en our fearful hearts it somewhat lighten'd,</br>To see those children, when the seaman's cry</br>Of "land in sight!"  their changing glances brighten'd,</br>Look round them with a hope-enkindled eye:</br>And one, a boy of thoughts and feelings high,</br>Far, far beyond his age, began to raise,</br>With all his young companions standing by,</br>Exulting hymns of gratitude and praise;</br>Until our fears were lull'd by their delightful lays.

And then the child, "with sense above his years,"</br>With narrative from Scripture's holy page</br>Beguil'd the terrors of his young compeers,</br>By showing who could Ocean's wrath assuage,</br>And calm the billows in their fiercest rage;</br>How He had rescued by his out-stretch'd arm</br>The Prophet Jonas in an earlier age;</br>Or how the word of Jesus, like a charm,</br>Once chain'd the winds and waves, and hush'd each vain alarm.

Alas!  sweet boy!  but wherefore mourn thy lot,</br>Or thy compeers' who sank beneath the wave?</br>Oh!  who shall deem you by your God forgot,</br>Though in life's bloom ye found a watery grave;</br>Though fruitless your heart-rending cries to save!</br>Amid the winds and waves distinctly heard;—</br>We know but this, — that He who being gave,</br>Resum'd the gift He had himself conferr'd,</br>Nor dare gainsay His will by one repining word.

Mysterious to our reason seems your doom;</br>Yet not less merciful that doom might be:</br>With your dear parents in that hour of gloom,</br>Which neither might nor skill of man could flee,</br>You gave, at Heaven's omnipotent decree,</br>Your innocent lives a spotless sacrifice;</br>And when the silent chambers of the sea</br>Shall hear the echoing trumpet rend the skies,</br>With them to meet the Lord in glory ye shall rise.

Then shall the wisdom of Omnipotence</br>To our illumin'd vision be made clear;</br>Marvels and mysteries unto mortal sense</br>Shall great, and good, and merciful appear;</br>Be our's that perfect love which casts out fear,</br>Dark doubt, and unbelief by faith's strong might,</br>And all things "seen in part and darkly" here,</br>Through the dim glass of reason's erring sight,</br>Shall be reveal'd to us in truth's unclouded light.

Peace to your spirits!  Your lamented fate,</br>Sweet innocents, has call'd me from our own;</br>Bidding my mournful tale anticipate</br>More than its narrative had erst made known;</br>Our fragile bark upon the reefs was thrown,</br>And soon was broken up; when all but nine,</br>To whom a transient respite yet was shown,</br>Were whelm'd beneath the darkly-heaving brine;</br>Unseen, but not unheard each sufferer's "parting sign."

We heard the children's feeble cries to save;—</br>Their parents' broken accents, while commending</br>Their souls to God!  with every wind and wave</br>Which broke around us some sad sound was blending;—</br>It was a scene all scenes of woe transcending</br>Which e'er had made my heart with anguish thrill;</br>Fearful to witness, painful in its ending,—</br>For, though each cry we heard our blood might chill,</br>As, one by one, they ceas'd, our hearts were colder still!

And we were left to brave that awful night,</br>Waiting for death, and musing on the dead;</br>Nor moon nor stars above us shed their light,</br>But the dark sky was like a pall o'er-spread;</br>Each coming wave, rearing its mountain head,</br>Threaten'd destruction; and the gusty blast</br>Howling around us, as it onward sped,</br>Reminded us of sounds for ever past,</br>The cries of drowning men, their saddest, and their last!

Slowly that long, long night was watch'd away;</br>Fond hope, that clings to life, reviv'd with light;</br>With trembling joy we hail'd its glimmering ray,</br>And saw it slowly chase the clouds of night;</br>The tops of hills then blest our eager sight,</br>The sea no more in mountain billows roll'd,</br>The glorious sun came forth in splendour bright;</br>Well might our sinking hearts become more bold,</br>When thus our eyes beheld another morn unfold.

In sight of land, with every chance to greet</br>Some wandering sail with aid approaching nigh,</br>Could our hearts fail with rising throbs to beat?</br>Or dark despair o'ercloud each anxious eye?</br>With hope that almost felt like certainty,</br>We made our signals to the neighbouring strand;</br>Trusting, believing some one must espy</br>Our puny pennon by the breezes fann'd,</br>And launch a friendly boat to bring our crew to land.

Not so; — the lingering, weary hours pass'd by,</br>And we were left in helpless suffering there;</br>To hear the dashing wave, — the sea-mew's cry;</br>In doubt, and dread, and "sad suspense to bear</br>The fearful hope that keeps alive despair:"</br>Bark after bark our desperate station near'd;</br>And when relief seem'd granted to our prayer,</br>When the chill'd heart reviving courage cheer'd,</br>Each vessel tack'd about, and from our vision steer'd.

Cruel it seem'd; — but we remain'd unheard,</br>Unseen, unpitied; — on the passing breeze</br>Was borne no sound which might with hope have stirr'd</br>Our spirits, sinking amid tossing seas:</br>Instead of this, — a sight our hearts to freeze,</br>Dead bodies floated by us on the wave,</br>Our late companions; — as we look'd on these,</br>Thus reft of life, and yet denied a grave,</br>We felt a sick'ning chill which palsies e'en the brave.

But though our hopes of aid from human power</br>With each fresh disappointment fainter grew,</br>God's might and mercy, in that dreadful hour</br>Sustain'd the spirits of the trembling few</br>Who look'd to Him alone; His power, we knew</br>Could bring deliverance though by man unseen,</br>We felt we were not hidden from his view,</br>Though nought beside was left whereon to lean;</br>And prayer to Him, at times, still kept our hearts serene.

It is not in the summer hours of life,</br>When all around is prosp'rous, bright, and gay,</br>That prayer's true worth is known; 'tis in the strife</br>Of fear and anguish, when we have no stay</br>On earth, or earthly things; Oh!  then we pray,</br>As those who know not sorrow never can:—</br>Each false support must first be rent away,</br>All confidence in self, all trust in man,</br>Rear-ward each worldly thought, each heavenly in the van,—

Before the place where living prayer is made</br>Can be attain'd unto, or audience won:—</br>Oh!  thus in earnestness to God we pray'd;</br>Beseeching Him, through his Redeeming Son,</br>To give us power to say, "Thy will be done!"</br>And thanks to Him who hears and answers prayer,</br>Our helpless wretchedness he did not shun,</br>Nor leave our hearts a prey to dark despair,</br>Though mine the only life his mercy deign'd to spare.

Lightly the worldling may our prayers esteem,</br>Since, save myself, all sank beneath the tide;</br>Not so the Christian of their worth will deem,</br>As if their richest blessing were denied;—</br>Not for our mortal life, alone, we cried,</br>But pray'd of Him whose word once still'd the wave,</br>The Pure, the Sinless, who for sinners died,</br>His power from death's most dreadful sting might save,</br>And give us through His Name the victory o'er the grave.

Thanks to His glorious name!  the strength of sin,</br>Its yoke of bondage, slavish fear of death,—</br>Were there subdued; our minds were calm within,</br>Sooth'd and sustain'd by holy living faith,</br>His gift, whose everlasting arm beneath</br>Preserv'd our spirits' better hopes unbroken;</br>And by the brethren, with their dying breath,</br>Much of the Saviour's power and love were spoken,</br>Making the cross He bore hope's sole surviving token.

Their words fell not upon regardless ears,</br>For hearts were tendered, spirits humbly bow'd;</br>And eyes, perchance 'till then unwet by tears</br>Of penitence, with sorrow overflow'd;</br>There was no dark obduracy to cloud</br>The light within, surpassing that of day;</br>Who could be doubtful, careless, cold, or proud,</br>Or who the Gospel's promises gainsay,</br>When life's last ebbing sands seem'd fleeting fast away.

And hence our fragment of a wreck became</br>A temple to the Lord!  who there was known;</br>There did He glorify His wondrous name</br>And make the light of his salvation shown;</br>Our hopes, our fears were turn'd to Him alone,</br>In frequent intervals of solemn thought,</br>And many a sigh, and tear, and prayer, and groan,</br>With more than rhetoric's richest graces fraught,</br>Meekly pour'd forth to Him his seat of mercy sought.

Three nights and days thus passed:  but months and years</br>Of common life more rapidly had sped!</br>So many griefs and sufferings, hopes and fears,</br>Were blended in each hour that o'er us sped:—</br>Oh!  when life hangs by such a slender thread,</br>How slowly, yet how swiftly moments fly;</br>Surrounded by the dying, and the dead,</br>The nights crept on, the days soon hurried by,</br>Each seeming, in its turn, to bring eternity!

Three days, and nights!  the sun arose, and set,</br>And set and rose; the Curlew sought her nest,</br>And came at morn, and found us ling'ring yet,</br>Waiting for death: — whether the glowing west</br>Shed its rich splendours over Ocean's breast,</br>Or the bright orient told another morn,</br>Or moon and stars proclaim'd the hour of rest</br>To all but us; — there watching, faint, and worn,</br>In sad suspense we sate, a waning band forlorn.

A waning band, for one by one was gone,</br>Exhausted, to the ocean depths below;</br>And we, who somewhat longer linger'd on,</br>Were worn with watching, weariness, and woe:—</br>The cry of sea-birds, flitting to and fro</br>Around the rocky reef whereon we lay,</br>The sound of dashing waves, whose ceaseless flow,</br>Drenched our spent bodies with their briny spray,—</br>Hour after hour endur'd, seem'd wasting life away.

One after one was taken.  Some in vain</br>Essay'd to swim unto the neighbouring shore;</br>Forlorn of hope they plung'd into the main,</br>With nerveless arm to brave the billows' roar;</br>Each after each they sank to rise no more:—</br>Alas!  each fruitless effort only made</br>Our lot seem lonelier than it was before;</br>For, as our dwindled numbers we survey'd,</br>Hope, — fear of being last on each survivor weigh'd.

Another, and another sank; and now</br>But three of all our crew were left behind,</br>He unto whom my lip had pledg'd a vow</br>Which closer seem'd in this sad hour to bind,—</br>Myself, and him to whom was erst assign'd</br>Our ship's command; — we three still feebly kept,</br>A little longer, life's faint spark enshrin'd</br>In frames o'er which death's icy coldness crept;—</br>Waking, we watch'd, and pray'd; by turns we briefly slept.

Yes, slept!  for e'en the wretched sink to sleep,</br>Though not to rest; — dark dreams of fearful gloom</br>Rise to such slumberers on the mighty deep,</br>Which seem like preludes of approaching doom;</br>Visions of monsters lurking in the womb</br>Of Ocean's plumbless depths their prey to seize;</br>Of corpses over which its billows boom,</br>Far, far below the sunshine and the breeze;</br>Of all, men dread or dare, who brave the stormy seas.

Mingled with these rose visions fair and bright,</br>Lovelier, but far more cruel, dreams of home;</br>Such as the home-sick bosoms oft delight</br>Of mourning exiles when afar they roam;</br>Instead of tossing waves with whitening foam,</br>Were purling brooks, with flowers beside them springing,</br>The dreamer's canopy, not heaven's wide dome,</br>But leafy trees, where happy birds were singing,</br>Or to whose topmost boughs the rooks were homeward winging.

But why the mockeries of dreams relate?</br>Enough was ours of dark reality</br>Which feverish dreams could scarcely aggravate;</br>Thirst, hunger, pining famine now drew nigh,</br>Parch'd was each lip, and blood-shot every eye,</br>All life's elastic energy seem'd flown;</br>Our words were faint, and few; a look, a sigh,</br>Or murmur'd sounds, like infant's feeble moan,</br>Feeling and thought express'd, and made our meaning known.

And now the fears whose agony had rent,</br>For its fond partner, my foreboding heart,</br>Drew near their last and dread accomplishment;</br>And though some melancholy tears might start,</br>To think that thus it was our lot to part!</br>I felt that sighs and tears alike were vain;</br>Could either have delay'd Death's menac'd dart,</br>Selfish it seem'd to wish he should remain</br>A prey to pining want, and long-protracted pain.

Yet all I could was done, in that sad hour,</br>To pillow on my breast his sinking head;</br>I could not bear the billows should devour</br>His wasted form 'till life's last spark had fled;</br>It seem'd Affection's sole surviving dread,</br>In that most painful climax of its woe,</br>That he should sink in Ocean's tossing bed,</br>Powerless to struggle, yet alive to know</br>The pangs of drowning men.  Thank God! — it was not so!

I could not minister to him — as those</br>Who in the peaceful chamber tend the dying;</br>Where all is hush'd to wait the awful close,</br>And even struggling grief finds vent in sighing;</br>Where fond Affection, still unwearied trying</br>Each blameless art its fancy can suggest,</br>Fresh palliatives for each new pain supplying,</br>Kisses the wan cheek on the pillow prest;—</br>By every languid smile for all its efforts blest.

Such were not in my power; I could but watch,</br>With mournful glance, his coldly glazing eye,</br>And changing features; thankful but to catch</br>Words to which tears forbade me to reply:—</br>Just ere the close a wave swept rudely by;</br>I call'd upon the Captain, in my dread,</br>"Oh raise him, in my arms, that he may die!"</br>He turn'd round to me, mournfully, and said,</br>"I, too, am almost gone!" — and soon his spirit fled.

But strength was given me, though my trembling clasp</br>Had else been powerless as a babe's might be,</br>To hold my dying husband in my grasp,</br>For this I knew he would have done for me,</br>'Till in my arms his spirit was set free,</br>"Jesus" — and "Glory" — falt'ring on his tongue;—</br>And ere I let him sink into the sea,</br>Much as my feelings were by anguish wrung,</br>To his eternal joy my spirit meekly clung.

I let him go!  the rushing waves clos'd o'er him,</br>My tears were check'd, and hush'd was ev'ry groan;</br>It seem'd unjust, unfeeling to deplore him,</br>Hoping, yea trusting that his soul had flown</br>To join the worshippers around the throne</br>Of God, and of the Lamb! — I now could bear</br>To linger out life's few brief hours alone,</br>And die the last sad helpless being there,</br>If his immortal bliss my deathless soul might share.

So was I left in solitude: — and found</br>By my deliverers — like some breathless thing</br>By fabled spell of old enchanter bound;</br>Or her whose woes the ancient poets sing;</br>Or form which statuary's art may bring</br>To mimic mortal life from lifeless clay;</br>A being — in whose breast life's hidden spring,</br>Chill'd at its fountain-head, forgets to play,—</br>Thus was I found, and thence, unconscious, borne away.

Such is my Story:  Reader, did I err</br>When I declared it one, whose deep distress</br>Each gentle source of sympathy might stir,</br>In hearts which feel for others' wretchedness?</br>Why have I told my sorrows?  but to press</br>Upon thy heart what they have taught to mine,</br>That those who in affliction strive to bless</br>A Father's rod, shall on his staff recline,</br>And in grief's darkest hour be cheer'd by Light Divine.

To them who live by faith, and not by sight,</br>The Lord will prove himself a God indeed;</br>Riches in poverty, in weakness might,</br>A present help in every time of need;</br>And should his love through death's dark chambers lead,</br>There shall his presence, in the fearful hour,</br>Give them a Saviour's sacrifice to plead,</br>And make them more than conq'rors in the power</br>Of Him whose holy name remains their fortress-tower.

Then glory, honour, worship, power, and praise,</br>Be given to HIM who sitteth on the throne!</br>Whose path is on the sea, whose wond'rous ways</br>Through the deep waters yet remain unknown;</br>The riches of whose mercy still are shown</br>To ALL who, trusting not their might, or skill,</br>In living faith look up to Him, alone;</br>Seeking, in every change of good or ill,</br>To magnify His name, and bless His holy will.</br>
